source.659d3221:
dataset_path = '/kaggle/input/car-crashes-severity-prediction/'

df = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(dataset_path, 'train.csv'))

print("The shape of the dataset is {}.\n\n".format(df.shape))

df.head()
source.fa33a991:
# Split the timestamp
year, month, day, hour = [], [], [], []

for t in df['timestamp']:
    date, time = t.split(" ")
    y, m, d = date.split('-')
    year.append(y)
    month.append(m)
    day.append(d)
    hour.append(time.split(":")[0])

df['Year'] = year
df['Month'] = month
df['Day'] = day
df['Hour'] = hour


# Read the weather and holiday data
weather_df = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(dataset_path, 'weather-sfcsv.csv'))

# Replace nulll values

# Read holiday data from xml
xml_data = open('/kaggle/input/car-crashes-severity-prediction/holidays.xml', 'r').read()  # Read file
root = ET.XML(xml_data)  # Parse XML

data = []
cols = []
for i, child in enumerate(root):
    data.append([subchild.text for subchild in child])
    cols.append(child.tag)
    
holiday_df = pd.DataFrame(data).T 
holiday_df.columns = cols 

holiday_df = holiday_df.T

# Create holiday value (true or false)
holidays = [x[:10] in list(holiday_df[0]) for x in df['timestamp']]


df['Holiday'] = holidays

newWeatherDF = pd.DataFrame()

for index, row in df.iterrows():
    wData = weather_df.loc[(weather_df['Year'] == int(row['Year'])) & (weather_df['Month'] == int(row['Month'])) & (weather_df['Day'] == int(row['Day']))]
    distances = abs(int(row['Hour']) - wData['Hour'])
    id_ = distances[distances == min(distances)].index[0]
    data = wData.loc[[id_]]
    newWeatherDF = newWeatherDF.append(data)

newWeatherDF.tail()
source.2219e8d0:
newWeatherDF = newWeatherDF.reset_index(drop=True)

result = pd.concat([df, newWeatherDF], axis=1, ignore_index=False)
result
source.116ac0a3:
# Fill the null values with the mean of the columns

res2 = pd.DataFrame(result)
res2['Wind_Chill(F)'] = res2['Wind_Chill(F)'].fillna(res2['Wind_Chill(F)'].mean())
res2['Precipitation(in)'] = res2['Precipitation(in)'].fillna(res2['Precipitation(in)'].mean())
res2['Temperature(F)'] = res2['Temperature(F)'].fillna(res2['Temperature(F)'].mean())
res2['Humidity(%)'] = res2['Humidity(%)'].fillna(res2['Humidity(%)'].mean())
res2['Wind_Speed(mph)'] = res2['Wind_Speed(mph)'].fillna(res2['Wind_Speed(mph)'].mean())

# Factorize categorical data
selectedFactorized, uniques = pd.factorize(res2['Selected'])
res2['Selected'] = selectedFactorized

selectedFactorized, uniques = pd.factorize(res2['Weather_Condition'])
res2['Weather_Condition'] = selectedFactorized

weatherFactorized, uniques = pd.factorize(res2['Weather_Condition'])
res2['Weather_Condition'] = weatherFactorized

sideFactorized, uniques = pd.factorize(res2['Side'])
res2['Side'] = sideFactorized

res2.head()
source.c009c65c:
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

train_df, val_df = train_test_split(res2, test_size=0.2, random_state=42) # Try adding `stratify` here

X_train = train_df.drop(columns=['ID', 'Severity'])
y_train = train_df['Severity']

X_val = val_df.drop(columns=['ID', 'Severity'])
y_val = val_df['Severity']
source.6902d72e:
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier

# Create an instance of the classifier
classifier = RandomForestClassifier(max_depth=2, random_state=0)

# Train the classifier
classifier = classifier.fit(X_train, y_train)
source.dc279186: print("The accuracy of the classifier on the validation set is ", (classifier.score(X_val, y_val)))
source.7c700e76:
# Split the timestamp
year, month, day, hour = [], [], [], []

for t in test_df['timestamp']:
    date, time = t.split(" ")
    y, m, d = date.split('-')
    year.append(y)
    month.append(m)
    day.append(d)
    hour.append(time.split(":")[0])
    
sideFactorized, uniques = pd.factorize(test_df['Side'])
test_df['Side'] = sideFactorized   
    
test_df['Year'] = year
test_df['Month'] = month
test_df['Day'] = day
test_df['Hour'] = hour

# Create holiday value (true or false)
holidays = [x[:10] in list(holiday_df[0]) for x in test_df['timestamp']]

test_df['Holiday'] = holidays

newWeatherDF = pd.DataFrame()

for index, row in test_df.iterrows():
    wData = weather_df.loc[(weather_df['Year'] == int(row['Year'])) & (weather_df['Month'] == int(row['Month'])) & (weather_df['Day'] == int(row['Day']))]
    distances = abs(int(row['Hour']) - wData['Hour'])
    id_ = distances[distances == min(distances)].index[0]
    data = wData.loc[[id_]]
    newWeatherDF = newWeatherDF.append(data)

newNewWeatherDF = newWeatherDF.drop(columns=['Year', 'Month', 'Day', 'Hour'])

newNewNewWeatherDF = newNewWeatherDF.reset_index(drop=True)

result = pd.concat([test_df, newNewNewWeatherDF], axis=1, ignore_index=False)

res2 = pd.DataFrame(result)
res2['Wind_Chill(F)'].fillna(res2['Wind_Chill(F)'].mean(), inplace=True)
res2['Precipitation(in)'].fillna(res2['Precipitation(in)'].mean(), inplace=True)
res2['Temperature(F)'].fillna(res2['Temperature(F)'].mean(), inplace=True)
res2['Humidity(%)'].fillna(res2['Humidity(%)'].mean(), inplace=True)
res2['Wind_Speed(mph)'].fillna(res2['Wind_Speed(mph)'].mean(), inplace=True)

# You should update/remove the next line once you change the features used for training
X_test = X_test[['Lat', 'Lng', 'Stop', 'Humidity(%)', 'Holiday']]

y_test_predicted = classifier.predict(X_test)

res2['Severity'] = y_test_predicted

        yticklabels=corr_df.columns, annot=True)

source.74b56adc:
## You're here! 
Welcome to your first competition in the [ITI's AI Pro training program](https://ai.iti.gov.eg/epita/ai-engineer/)! We hope you enjoy and learn as much as we did prepairing this competition.


## Introduction

In the competition, it's required to predict the `Severity` of a car crash given info about the crash, e.g., location.

This is the getting started notebook. Things are kept simple so that it's easier to understand the steps and modify it.

Feel free to `Fork` this notebook and share it with your modifications **OR** use it to create your submissions.

### Prerequisites
You should know how to use python and a little bit of Machine Learning. You can apply the techniques you learned in the training program and submit the new solutions! 

### Checklist
You can participate in this competition the way you perefer. However, I recommend following these steps if this is your first time joining a competition on Kaggle.

* Fork this notebook and run the cells in order.
* Submit this solution.
* Make changes to the data processing step as you see fit.
* Submit the new solutions.

*You can submit up to 5 submissions per day. You can select only one of the submission you make to be considered in the final ranking.*


Don't hesitate to leave a comment or contact me if you have any question!

source.e3d6277d:
## Conclusion

In this notebook, we have demonstrated the essential steps that one should do in order to get "slightly" familiar with the data and the submission process. We chose not to go into details in each step to keep the welcoming notebook simple and make a room for improvement.

You're encourged to `Fork` the notebook, edit it, add your insights and use it to create your submission.
source.5d7e5f15:
## Submission File Generation

We have built a model and we'd like to submit our predictions on the test set! In order to do that, we'll load the test set, predict the class and save the submission file. 

First, we'll load the data.
source.78157179:
The remaining steps is to submit the generated file and are as follows. 

1. Press `Save Version` on the upper right corner of this notebook.
2. Write a `Version Name` of your choice and choose `Save & Run All (Commit)` then click `Save`.
3. Wait for the saved notebook to finish running the go to the saved notebook.
4. Scroll down until you see the output files then select the `submission.csv` file and click `Submit`.

Now your submission will be evaluated and your score will be updated on the leaderboard! CONGRATULATIONS!!

source.a354330c:
Note that the test set has the same features and doesn't have the `Severity` column.
At this stage one must **NOT** forget to apply the same processing done on the training set on the features of the test set.

Now we'll add `Severity` column to the test `DataFrame` and add the values of the predicted class to it.

**I'll select the numerical features here as I did in the training set. DO NOT forget to change this step as you change the preprocessing of the training data.**
source.ccf57fd0:
## Data Splitting

Now it's time to split the dataset for the training step. Typically the dataset is split into 3 subsets, namely, the training, validation and test sets. In our case, the test set is already predefined. So we'll split the "training" set into training and validation sets with 0.8:0.2 ratio. 

*Note: a good way to generate reproducible results is to set the seed to the algorithms that depends on randomization. This is done with the argument `random_state` in the following command*
source.8ef9632b: Now let's test our classifier on the validation dataset and see the accuracy.
